Key Terminology True Experiment: A design with random assignment, manipulation of the independent variable, and control of extraneous variables Quasi-Experiment: A design lacking random assignment but including manipulation of the independent variable Random Assignment: Procedure ensuring each participant has an equal chance of being assigned to any condition Control Group: A comparison condition that does not receive the experimental treatment Between-Subjects Design: Different participants in each condition Within-Subjects Design: Same participants tested in all conditions

Solomon Four-Group Design Structure Group 1: Pretest → Treatment → Posttest Group 2: Pretest → No Treatment → Posttest Group 3: No Pretest → Treatment → Posttest Group 4: No Pretest → No Treatment → Posttest

ABAB Design Logic The withdrawal phase tests whether behavior is maintained by the treatment. If improvements persist after treatment withdrawal, the treatment may have produced lasting change—or other factors may be responsible for the improvement. If behavior returns to baseline levels during withdrawal, this strengthens the inference that the treatment was responsible for initial improvement

Cohort-Sequential Design The cohort-sequential design combines cross-sectional and longitudinal approaches by following multiple cohorts over time. This allows researchers to separate age effects, cohort effects, and time-of-measurement effects

Counterbalancing Counterbalancing addresses order effects by varying the sequence of conditions across participants. In complete counterbalancing, all possible orders are used equally. In Latin square counterbalancing, a subset of orders is used such that each condition appears equally often in each position

Clinical Considerations In clinical settings, quasi-experimental designs are often the most feasible option. For example, comparing outcomes between patients who choose medication versus therapy cannot use random assignment ethically if patients have strong preferences. Careful matching and statistical controls can strengthen causal inferences in such studies

Ethical Considerations ABAB designs may be inappropriate when withdrawal of an effective treatment poses risks to the client (e.g., self-injurious behavior). In such cases, multiple baseline designs provide an ethical alternative that maintains experimental control without requiring treatment withdrawal

passages.section: Quality and Rigor in Qualitative Research
passages.passage: Qualitative vs. Quantitative: Complementary Approaches Quantitative: Tests hypotheses, measures variables, uses statistics, seeks generalizable findings, large samples Qualitative: Explores meaning, describes experiences, uses thematic analysis, seeks depth and context, smaller samples Mixed methods: Combines both approaches in a single study to leverage the strengths of each. Sequential designs use one method to inform the other; concurrent designs collect both types of data simultaneously

Program Evaluation vs. Research Purpose: Research seeks generalizable knowledge; evaluation informs specific program decisions Audience: Research targets the scientific community; evaluation targets stakeholders and decision-makers Design priority: Research emphasizes internal validity; evaluation balances rigor with practical constraints IRB review: Both may require IRB approval, but program evaluation that is purely for quality improvement (not generalizable) may be exempt

Research Example A researcher randomly assigns 60 patients with depression to either cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) or a waitlist control. Both groups complete the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) before and after the 12-week treatment period. The researcher can compare change scores between groups to determine if CBT produces significantly greater improvement than the passage of time alone

Factorial Design Example A researcher examines the effects of therapy type (CBT vs. psychodynamic) and medication (present vs. absent) on anxiety symptoms using a 2 × 2 factorial design. This allows examination of: (1) the main effect of therapy type, (2) the main effect of medication, and (3) the interaction between therapy and medication (e.g., whether CBT is particularly effective when combined with medication)

Time-Series Example A hospital implements a new suicide prevention protocol and tracks monthly suicide attempts for two years before and two years after implementation. By examining the pattern of data points, researchers can determine whether the intervention was associated with a change in level or trend of suicide attempts

Multiple Baseline Across Behaviors A therapist targets three problem behaviors in a child with autism: hand-flapping, echolalia, and tantrums. After establishing baselines for all three, she implements a token economy first for hand-flapping. Once reduction is observed, she extends the intervention to echolalia, then to tantrums. If each behavior decreases only when the intervention is applied to it, this demonstrates experimental control without requiring withdrawal

Research design refers to the overall strategy that integrates the different components of a study in a coherent and logical manner, ensuring the research problem is effectively addressed. The choice of research design determines the type of conclusions that can be drawn from a study, particularly regarding causation . Understanding research designs is essential for psychologists who must evaluate the quality of evidence supporting clinical interventions and make evidence-based decisions in practice

Research designs exist on a continuum of internal validity , with true experimental designs providing the strongest evidence for causal inference and observational designs providing the weakest. However, designs with lower internal validity may have advantages in external validity or practical feasibility (Cook & Campbell, 1979)

True experimental designs are characterized by three essential features: (1) manipulation of at least one independent variable, (2) random assignment of participants to conditions, and (3) control over extraneous variables. These features allow researchers to make strong causal inferences about the relationship between the independent and dependent variables

The pretest-posttest control group design includes random assignment of participants to treatment and control groups, with measurements taken before and after treatment. This design allows researchers to assess change over time and control for pre-existing differences between groups

When pretesting may sensitize participants to the treatment or when random assignment is expected to produce equivalent groups, researchers may use a posttest-only control group design . This design omits the pretest, relying on random assignment to equate groups prior to treatment

The Solomon four-group design combines elements of both previous designs, using four groups: two receive pretests (one treatment, one control) and two do not (one treatment, one control). This design allows researchers to detect and control for testing effects and sensitization

Factorial designs manipulate two or more independent variables simultaneously, allowing researchers to examine both main effects and interaction effects. A 2 × 2 factorial design, for example, has two independent variables, each with two levels, creating four conditions

Quasi-experimental designs lack random assignment but still involve manipulation of an independent variable. These designs are commonly used in applied settings where random assignment is impractical or unethical . While they provide weaker evidence for causation than true experiments, thoughtful quasi-experimental designs can yield valuable findings

The nonequivalent control group design resembles the pretest-posttest control group design but lacks random assignment. Participants are assigned to conditions based on pre-existing group membership (e.g., students in different classrooms). The pretest helps assess initial group equivalence and can be used as a covariate in analysis

The interrupted time-series design involves multiple measurements before and after an intervention, allowing researchers to examine trends over time and detect changes associated with the intervention. This design is particularly useful for evaluating policy changes or community-level interventions

The regression discontinuity design assigns participants to conditions based on a cutoff score on a pretest measure. Those above the cutoff receive one treatment while those below receive another. The design examines whether there is a discontinuity (jump or drop) in the outcome variable at the cutoff point, which would indicate a treatment effect
This design has stronger internal validity than other quasi-experimental designs because assignment is based on a known, measured variable

Single-subject designs, also called single-case experimental designs or N-of-1 designs, use individual participants as their own controls. These designs involve repeated measurement of behavior over time and systematic introduction and withdrawal of interventions. They are widely used in applied behavior analysis and clinical psychology

The simplest single-subject design is the AB design , consisting of a baseline phase (A) followed by a treatment phase (B). While useful for clinical monitoring, this design provides weak evidence for causation because changes could be due to maturation, history, or other factors rather than the treatment

The ABAB design strengthens causal inference by adding withdrawal and reintroduction phases. The sequence is: baseline (A) → treatment (B) → withdrawal (A) → treatment (B). If behavior improves during treatment phases and deteriorates during withdrawal phases, this provides compelling evidence that the treatment caused the change

The multiple baseline design introduces treatment at different points in time across multiple baselines. These baselines can be across behaviors (different behaviors in one person), across subjects (same behavior in different people), or across settings (same behavior and person in different environments)

The changing criterion design involves systematically changing the criterion for reinforcement over time. Experimental control is demonstrated when behavior changes to match each new criterion. This design is particularly useful for shaping behaviors that should increase or decrease gradually (Hartmann & Hall, 1976)

The alternating treatments design (also called multi-element design) rapidly alternates between two or more treatments, with different treatments applied in counterbalanced order. This allows direct comparison of treatment effectiveness within a single subject

Non-experimental designs do not manipulate independent variables and therefore cannot establish causation. However, they are valuable for describing phenomena, identifying relationships, and generating hypotheses. These designs are often the only option when manipulation is impossible or unethical

Correlational research examines relationships between variables without manipulation. While correlation does not imply causation, sophisticated correlational techniques such as structural equation modeling and path analysis can test theoretical models about causal relationships

Survey research uses questionnaires or interviews to collect data from a sample, typically to describe characteristics of a population or examine relationships between variables. Representative sampling is critical for generalizing survey results to the population of interest

Cross-sectional designs collect data at a single point in time, comparing different groups (e.g., different age groups) simultaneously. While efficient, they cannot distinguish age effects from cohort effects
Longitudinal designs follow the same participants over time, allowing researchers to track individual change and development. However, they are expensive, time-consuming, and vulnerable to attrition

Case-control studies compare individuals with a condition (cases) to similar individuals without the condition (controls), examining differences in past exposures or characteristics. These retrospective designs are efficient for studying rare conditions but are vulnerable to recall bias and cannot establish causation

Cohort studies follow groups with different exposures forward in time to observe differences in outcomes. Prospective cohort studies are stronger than retrospective designs because exposure is measured before outcomes occur, reducing certain biases

In between-subjects designs , different participants are assigned to each condition. Random assignment creates groups that are expected to be equivalent on all variables except the independent variable. The main advantage is avoiding carryover effects; the main disadvantage is requiring more participants and introducing error variance from individual differences

In within-subjects designs , the same participants experience all conditions. This eliminates individual difference variance and requires fewer participants. However, these designs are vulnerable to order effects, including practice effects, fatigue, and carryover

Mixed designs (also called split-plot designs) include both between-subjects and within-subjects factors. For example, a study might compare two therapy groups (between-subjects) measured at multiple time points (within-subjects)

The method used to select participants affects the generalizability of research findings. Probability sampling methods give every member of the population a known, nonzero chance of selection, supporting statistical generalization

Nonprobability sampling methods do not ensure every member has a chance of selection. These include convenience sampling (readily available participants), purposive sampling (participants selected for specific characteristics), and snowball sampling (participants recruit other participants)

Qualitative research aims to understand phenomena through rich, in-depth description rather than numerical measurement. While quantitative methods test hypotheses and measure variables, qualitative methods explore the meanings, experiences, and processes underlying human behavior. Qualitative approaches are particularly valuable when a topic is poorly understood, when context matters, or when the research question asks "how" or "why" rather than "how much" (Creswell & Poth, 2018)

Grounded theory aims to generate theory from data rather than testing pre-existing hypotheses. Researchers collect data (typically through interviews and observations), code it systematically, and develop theoretical concepts that are "grounded" in the data. The process involves open coding (identifying initial categories), axial coding (relating categories), and selective coding (integrating into a coherent theory). Data collection and analysis occur simultaneously, and theoretical sampling guides recruitment—new participants are selected to refine emerging theory (Glaser & Strauss, 1967)

Phenomenology seeks to describe the essence of lived experience as perceived by participants. Researchers conduct in-depth interviews to understand how individuals experience a particular phenomenon (e.g., living with chronic pain, experiencing grief). The analyst identifies themes and structures that capture the core meaning of the experience. The researcher engages in bracketing (also called epoché)—setting aside personal preconceptions to focus on participants' subjective experiences

Ethnography involves prolonged immersion in a cultural group or community to understand its practices, beliefs, and social dynamics from an insider perspective. The researcher engages in participant observation —simultaneously participating in and observing the culture. Ethnographic studies produce thick description , which captures not just behaviors but their context and meaning

The case study approach involves in-depth examination of a single case or a small number of cases. A "case" can be an individual, a program, an organization, or an event. Case studies use multiple data sources (interviews, documents, observations) and are valuable for exploring complex phenomena in real-world contexts. They provide rich detail but have limited generalizability

Narrative analysis examines the stories people tell about their lives and experiences. Researchers analyze how individuals construct meaning through narrative structure, plot, characters, and sequencing. This approach recognizes that people organize their understanding of the world through stories and that narratives reveal identity, culture, and values

Program evaluation is the systematic collection and analysis of information to make judgments about programs, policies, or interventions. Unlike basic research, which aims to generate new knowledge, program evaluation is applied—it informs decisions about whether to continue, modify, expand, or terminate a program . Program evaluation draws on research design principles but prioritizes practical utility and stakeholder needs

A needs assessment is conducted before program design to identify the needs of the target population and determine whether a program is warranted. It answers the question: "What problems exist and what services are needed?" Methods include surveys, interviews, focus groups, and analysis of existing data (e.g., community health statistics)

Process evaluation (also called implementation evaluation) monitors whether the program is being delivered as intended. It assesses implementation fidelity —the degree to which the program follows its designed protocol. Process evaluation answers: "Is the program being carried out as planned? Are participants being reached? Are services being delivered correctly?"

Outcome evaluation measures whether program goals and objectives were achieved. It examines the direct, intended effects of the program on participants. For example, did a smoking cessation program lead to reduced smoking rates among participants? Outcome evaluations typically use pre-post designs or comparison groups

Impact evaluation examines the broader, long-term effects of a program on the community or population beyond the immediate participants. It assesses whether the program produced lasting change and whether effects generalized beyond the target group. Impact evaluations are more comprehensive than outcome evaluations and often examine unintended consequences as well

Empowerment evaluation , developed by David Fetterman, is a participatory approach in which program stakeholders (staff, participants, community members) are trained to conduct their own evaluations. The evaluator serves as a facilitator or coach rather than an external judge. The goal is to build the program's internal capacity for self-evaluation and continuous improvement

Michael Quinn Patton's utilization-focused evaluation is designed from the outset to be useful to its intended users. Rather than prescribing a specific methodology, this approach begins by identifying the primary intended users and their information needs, then tailors the evaluation design to ensure findings will actually be used for decision-making

Four Types of Research Validity Internal Validity: Did the treatment (IV) actually cause the observed effect (DV)? External Validity: Can the findings be generalized to other people, settings, and times? Construct Validity: Are we measuring the constructs we think we're measuring? Statistical Conclusion Validity: Are our statistical conclusions accurate?

Additional Internal Validity Threats Diffusion of Treatment: Control group participants learn about or receive aspects of the treatment. Compensatory Equalization: Administrators provide extra services to the control group to compensate for not receiving treatment. Compensatory Rivalry: Control group participants work harder to compete with the treatment group (John Henry effect). Resentful Demoralization: Control group participants become demoralized and perform worse than they otherwise would

The Trade-off High Control (Lab): Strong internal validity, weaker external validity. We know the treatment works in controlled conditions but may not generalize to the real world. Naturalistic Settings (Field): Stronger external validity, weaker internal validity. Results generalize better, but we're less certain the treatment caused the effects

Clinical Implications: Generalizability When applying research findings to practice, clinicians must consider whether results generalize to their specific clients and settings. If a treatment was validated primarily on white, middle-class college students, its effectiveness with diverse clinical populations should be evaluated carefully. Evidence-based practice requires attention to both internal validity (does it work?) and external validity (will it work for my clients?)

Understanding the Distinction Random assignment controls internal validity threats by ensuring groups are equivalent. Random selection (from the population to the sample) controls external validity threats by ensuring the sample represents the population. Many students confuse these concepts on the EPPP. Random assignment creates equivalent groups; random selection creates representative samples

Example: History Threat A researcher studies the effect of a new anxiety treatment over 8 weeks. During the study, a major national crisis occurs, elevating anxiety in the population. Any observed changes in anxiety might be due to the treatment, the crisis, or both. The external event (crisis) is a history threat

Example: Regression Threat A school identifies students with the lowest reading scores for a remedial program. Even without any intervention, these students would likely score somewhat higher on a second test simply because their extreme scores were partly due to measurement error (bad day, unlucky guesses). Any improvement might be regression, not program effects

Research validity refers to the accuracy and trustworthiness of research conclusions. In the context of research methodology, validity concerns whether a study truly measures what it claims to measure and whether its conclusions are justified. Understanding different types of validity and the threats to each is essential for evaluating psychological research and designing rigorous studies

Campbell and colleagues distinguished four major types of validity in research: internal validity, external validity, construct validity, and statistical conclusion validity. Each addresses different questions about research quality, and understanding these distinctions is heavily tested on the EPPP

Internal validity refers to the degree to which a study establishes a causal relationship between the independent and dependent variables. A study has high internal validity when we can confidently conclude that changes in the DV were caused by the IV, not by other factors. True experiments with random assignment have the highest internal validity

Campbell and Stanley (1963) and later Cook and Campbell (1979) identified numerous threats to internal validity. These are alternative explanations for observed effects that compete with the interpretation that the IV caused changes in the DV
History refers to external events occurring during the study that may affect the dependent variable. These events are not part of the treatment but happen between pretest and posttest measurements

Maturation refers to natural changes in participants over time, such as growing older, becoming tired, or gaining experience. These changes occur regardless of treatment and may be mistaken for treatment effects

Testing (also called practice effects) occurs when taking a pretest affects performance on a posttest. Participants may remember items, become test-wise, or become sensitized to what the researcher is measuring

Instrumentation refers to changes in the measuring instrument or procedure during the study. This includes observer drift (observers changing their rating criteria over time), equipment calibration changes, or modified administration procedures

Statistical regression (regression to the mean) occurs when participants are selected based on extreme scores. Extreme scores tend to move toward the mean on retesting due to measurement error, regardless of any treatment effect

Selection occurs when groups differ systematically before treatment. This is a major threat in non-randomized studies. If the treatment group differs from the comparison group on relevant characteristics, any observed differences could be due to pre-existing differences rather than treatment

Mortality (or attrition) refers to differential dropout from groups during the study. If participants who drop out differ systematically from those who remain (and if dropout rates differ between groups), results may be biased
Selection can interact with other threats. Selection-maturation occurs when groups mature at different rates. Selection-history occurs when groups are differentially affected by external events

External validity (also called generalizability) refers to the degree to which research findings can be generalized beyond the specific conditions of the study. External validity addresses whether results apply to different populations, settings, times, and variations of the treatment

Results may apply only to the specific type of participants studied. For example, a treatment effective for college students might not work for older adults. Volunteer bias is a common form—volunteers may differ from non-volunteers in motivation or characteristics

Results from one setting may not generalize to others. Laboratory findings may not translate to real-world contexts. A therapy effective in a university clinic may not work in a community mental health center
Results may be specific to a particular time period. Findings from decades past may not apply today due to cultural, technological, or social changes
Pretesting may sensitize participants to the treatment, and without pretesting, results might differ. The treatment effect may depend on the pretest having occurred
When participants receive multiple treatments, effects of earlier treatments may persist and influence responses to later treatments. Order effects and carryover effects fall into this category

There is often tension between maximizing internal and external validity. Laboratory experiments with tight controls maximize internal validity but may have limited external validity. Field studies in naturalistic settings may have greater external validity but face more threats to internal validity
Researchers address this trade-off through programmatic research—conducting multiple studies that vary in methodology to build evidence that is both internally valid and generalizable

Construct validity in research refers to the degree to which the independent and dependent variables represent the theoretical constructs of interest. This is distinct from test validity (covered in later chapters) and addresses whether the operational definitions used in research adequately capture the intended constructs
Poor or incomplete definition of the constructs being studied leads to operationalizations that miss important aspects of the construct or include irrelevant elements
Using only one operationalization of a construct. A single measure captures only part of a construct and includes irrelevant variance. Multiple operationalizations provide stronger evidence

Using only one method of measurement. Shared method variance may inflate relationships. Using multiple methods (e.g., self-report, behavioral observation, physiological measures) provides stronger evidence
Participants guess what the study is about and alter their behavior accordingly. Demand characteristics lead participants to behave as they think the researcher expects
Researchers' expectations influence participant behavior or data interpretation. Double-blind procedures control for this threat

When the operationalization of one construct is confounded with another construct. For example, a treatment that includes both cognitive restructuring and relaxation training confounds these two components

Statistical conclusion validity refers to the appropriateness of the statistical methods used and the accuracy of conclusions about relationships or differences based on statistical analysis. Poor statistical conclusion validity leads to incorrect inferences about whether relationships exist and how strong they are
When a study has insufficient power to detect a true effect, the researcher may incorrectly conclude no effect exists (Type II error). Small samples and high variability reduce power
Using statistical tests when their assumptions are violated (e.g., normality, homogeneity of variance) can lead to inaccurate conclusions
Conducting multiple statistical tests without correction inflates the probability of Type I errors. "Fishing" for significant results capitalizes on chance
Unreliable measures attenuate observed relationships. Low reliability in either IV manipulation or DV measurement reduces the ability to detect true effects
Limited variability in scores attenuates correlations and reduces the ability to detect relationships that exist in the population

passages.passage: Key Terminology Validity: The degree to which evidence supports the intended interpretation of test scores for a specific purpose Validation: The ongoing process of accumulating evidence to support score interpretations Validity Coefficient: A correlation between test scores and a criterion measure Construct: A theoretical concept or attribute that a test is designed to measure

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Establishing Content Validity Domain definition: Clearly specify the content domain to be measured Test blueprint: Create a table of specifications linking items to content areas Expert review: Have subject matter experts evaluate item relevance and representativeness Content validity ratio (CVR): Quantify agreement among experts about item essentiality

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.section: Evidence Based on Relations to Other Variables
passages.passage: Multitrait-Multimethod Matrix Campbell and Fiske (1959) introduced the multitrait-multimethod (MTMM) matrix to evaluate both convergent and discriminant validity simultaneously. The matrix examines correlations among multiple traits measured by multiple methods. Convergent validity: High correlations between the same trait measured by different methods (monotrait-heteromethod) Discriminant validity: Lower correlations between different traits, even when measured by the same method (heterotrait-monomethod)

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Bias vs. Fairness Bias is a statistical/psychometric concept referring to systematic measurement error. Fairness is a broader concept encompassing social values and judgments about appropriate test use. A test can be psychometrically unbiased yet still raise fairness concerns if its use produces adverse impact on protected groups

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Key Relationships Validity cannot exceed the square root of reliability: r xy ≤ √r xx High reliability does not guarantee validity Low reliability limits the maximum possible validity Both reliability and validity are essential for meaningful measurement

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Response Process Investigation If a reading comprehension test is designed to measure inference-making, validity evidence should demonstrate that examinees actually make inferences to answer questions, rather than relying on prior knowledge or test-taking strategies that bypass the intended processes

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Addressing Construct Validity Threats Underrepresentation: Ensure comprehensive sampling of the construct domain; use multiple item formats Irrelevant variance: Minimize irrelevant difficulty sources; provide accommodations when appropriate; evaluate differential item functioning across groups

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Evaluating Test Bias Compare regression equations across groups (intercepts and slopes) Conduct DIF analyses to identify problematic items Examine whether content represents all groups fairly Consider the consequences of test use for different groups

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Content Validity Example A licensing exam for clinical psychologists should sample knowledge across relevant domains: assessment, diagnosis, treatment, ethics, and research methods. If the exam heavily emphasizes one area while neglecting others, it would have poor content validity for measuring overall competence in clinical psychology

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Factor Analysis Example An anxiety measure theorized to assess three components (cognitive, somatic, behavioral) should show three distinct factors in factor analysis. If items from different subscales load on the same factor, or if a single general factor emerges, the theoretical structure is not supported

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Nomological Network for Intelligence The nomological network for intelligence includes theoretical relationships (intelligence should correlate positively with academic achievement, problem-solving ability, and processing speed) and observable indicators (IQ scores should predict school grades, job performance in complex occupations, and performance on cognitive tasks). Evidence supporting these relationships strengthens construct validity

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Validity Generalization Example Meta-analyses of cognitive ability tests show that their validity for predicting job performance generalizes across jobs and settings, with corrected validity coefficients typically ranging from .50 to .60 for overall job performance. This suggests that cognitive ability is a valid predictor across many employment contexts

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Reliability-Validity Relationship A weight scale might reliably measure weight (high reliability) but would have no validity for measuring intelligence. Conversely, a test with reliability of .64 can have maximum validity of only √.64 = .80, regardless of how well the content represents the intended construct

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Validity is the most fundamental consideration in test development and use. It refers to the degree to which evidence and theory support the interpretations of test scores for proposed uses. Unlike reliability, which concerns consistency of measurement, validity addresses whether a test actually measures what it claims to measure and whether inferences drawn from scores are appropriate (AERA et al., 2014)

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Contemporary validity theory emphasizes that validity is not a property of the test itself, but rather of the interpretations and uses of test scores. A test may be valid for one purpose (e.g., screening for depression) but not for another (e.g., diagnosing specific depressive disorders). Messick (1989) articulated an influential unitary concept of validity, arguing that all validity evidence relates to construct validity

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: The Standards for Educational and Psychological Testing (AERA et al., 2014) identifies five major sources of validity evidence. Each provides different information about the appropriateness of score interpretations

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Content validity refers to the degree to which test items adequately sample the domain of content the test is intended to measure. It is established through logical analysis rather than statistical procedures and is particularly important for achievement tests and job performance assessments

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Face validity refers to whether a test appears to measure what it claims to measure, from the perspective of examinees or untrained observers. While not technically a form of validity evidence, face validity can affect examinee motivation, public acceptance, and perceived fairness. A test can have good construct validity but poor face validity, or vice versa

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: This type of evidence examines whether examinees actually engage in the cognitive processes the test intends to measure. Methods include think-aloud protocols, eye-tracking studies, and analysis of response patterns

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Internal structure evidence examines whether the relationships among test items and components conform to the theoretical structure of the construct. Factor analysis is the primary statistical technique for evaluating internal structure

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Exploratory factor analysis (EFA) identifies the underlying factor structure without prior hypotheses about the number or nature of factors. Confirmatory factor analysis (CFA) tests whether data fit a hypothesized factor structure based on theory

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.section: Evidence Based on Relations to Other Variables
passages.passage: This evidence demonstrates that test scores relate to external variables in ways consistent with the theoretical understanding of the construct. This category includes convergent and discriminant validity evidence, as well as criterion-related validity

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.section: Evidence Based on Relations to Other Variables
passages.passage: Convergent validity is demonstrated when a test correlates strongly with other measures of the same or similar constructs. High correlations with conceptually related measures support the interpretation that the test measures the intended construct

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.section: Evidence Based on Relations to Other Variables
passages.passage: Discriminant validity is demonstrated when a test shows low correlations with measures of theoretically unrelated constructs. This evidence supports the distinctiveness of the measured construct

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.section: Evidence Based on Consequences of Testing
passages.passage: This evidence considers the intended and unintended consequences of test use, including potential benefits and harms. It addresses whether test use achieves its intended outcomes and whether any negative consequences are related to construct-irrelevant factors such as bias

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Construct validity is the overarching concept that encompasses all validity evidence. It addresses the fundamental question: Does the test measure the theoretical construct it purports to measure? All other forms of validity evidence contribute to construct validity (Cronbach & Meehl, 1955)

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Cronbach and Meehl (1955) introduced the concept of a nomological network —the theoretical framework specifying the relationships between a construct and other constructs, as well as observable manifestations. Validity evidence supports or challenges elements of this network

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Construct underrepresentation occurs when a test fails to capture important aspects of the construct. The test is too narrow, measuring only part of what it should measure

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Construct-irrelevant variance occurs when test scores are influenced by factors unrelated to the construct. These irrelevant factors can include test anxiety, reading ability on non-reading tests, or cultural bias

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Validity generalization refers to the extent to which validity evidence obtained in one context applies to other contexts, populations, or situations. Schmidt and Hunter (1977) demonstrated that much apparent variability in validity coefficients across studies reflects statistical artifacts (sampling error, range restriction, measurement error) rather than true differences

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Test bias is a psychometric concept referring to systematic errors in test scores or predictions for members of particular groups. A test is considered biased if it systematically over- or underpredicts criterion performance for certain groups

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Predictive bias exists when a test's regression line for predicting a criterion differs across groups. If the same test score predicts different criterion levels for different groups, selection decisions based on the test may be unfair

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Differential item functioning occurs when examinees of equal ability from different groups have different probabilities of answering an item correctly. DIF analysis identifies potentially biased items that may function differently across demographic groups

passages.chapter_title: Measuring What Matters: Content & Construct Validity
passages.passage: Reliability is necessary but not sufficient for validity. A test cannot measure a construct accurately (be valid) if it does not measure consistently (be reliable). However, a test can be highly reliable while measuring the wrong construct

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Key Terminology Variable: Any characteristic that can vary or take on different values Constant: A characteristic that does not change across observations Operationalization: The process of defining a variable in terms of specific, measurable procedures Measurement: The assignment of numbers to objects or events according to rules

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Summary: Scales of Measurement (NOIR) Scale Properties Example Central Tendency Nominal Categories only Diagnosis, gender Mode Ordinal Rank order Class rank, severity ratings Median Interval Equal intervals, no true zero Temperature, IQ scores Mean Ratio Equal intervals, true zero Reaction time, height Mean

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Computational Formulas Variance (sample): s² = Σ(X - M)² / (n - 1) Standard Deviation: s = √s² The divisor (n - 1) is called degrees of freedom and provides an unbiased estimate of the population parameter

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: The Empirical Rule (68-95-99.7) In a normal distribution: 68% of observations fall between M - 1SD and M + 1SD 95% of observations fall between M - 2SD and M + 2SD 99.7% of observations fall between M - 3SD and M + 3SD

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Z-Score Formula z = (X - M) / SD Where X is the raw score, M is the mean, and SD is the standard deviation. The z-score distribution always has a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Special Percentiles: Quartiles Q1 (25th percentile): First quartile—25% of scores fall below Q2 (50th percentile): Second quartile—the median Q3 (75th percentile): Third quartile—75% of scores fall below Interquartile Range (IQR): Q3 - Q1, contains middle 50% of scores

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Control Techniques Random assignment: Distributes individual differences across conditions Matching: Ensures groups are equivalent on specific variables Holding constant: Keeps a variable at one level across all conditions Counterbalancing: Varies order of conditions to control sequence effects Statistical control: Uses ANCOVA or partial correlation to remove effects

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Choosing the Right Measure Use the mean when the distribution is relatively normal and outliers are absent. Use the median when the distribution is skewed or contains outliers (e.g., income data). Use the mode for nominal data or to identify the most common category

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Practical Implications Severe skewness or kurtosis can violate assumptions of parametric statistical tests. Options include: Using nonparametric alternatives Transforming data (log, square root) Using robust statistical methods Reporting median instead of mean for skewed data

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Interpreting Test Scores When interpreting psychological test scores, percentile ranks are often more intuitive for clients than standard scores. However, percentile ranks have important limitations: They are not equal-interval—a difference of 10 percentile points near the mean represents fewer raw score points than the same difference at the extremes They cannot be meaningfully averaged or subjected to arithmetic operations They should not be compared across different normative samples

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Research Example In a study examining the effects of sleep deprivation on memory, the researcher manipulates hours of sleep (IV: 8 hours vs. 4 hours) and measures performance on a memory test (DV). The dependent variable "depends on" the level of the independent variable

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Mediator vs. Moderator Mediator example: Therapy → Increased self-efficacy → Decreased depression. Self-efficacy mediates the relationship between therapy and depression by explaining how therapy works. Moderator example: The effect of therapy on depression is stronger for patients with high motivation (motivation moderates the therapy-depression relationship by explaining when therapy works best)

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Z-Score Calculation Example On a test with M = 100 and SD = 15, a score of 130 has a z-score of: z = (130 - 100) / 15 = 30 / 15 = 2.0 This score is 2 standard deviations above the mean, falling at approximately the 98th percentile in a normal distribution

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Skewness Examples Positive skew: Income distribution (many low-to-moderate incomes, few very high incomes pulling the mean up) Negative skew: Age at death in developed countries (most people live to old age, with some early deaths pulling the mean down)

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Variables are characteristics or attributes that can take on different values across individuals, time, or conditions. Understanding the types of variables and how they are measured is fundamental to psychological research and assessment. The nature of a variable determines which statistical analyses are appropriate and what conclusions can be drawn from data (Gravetter & Wallnau, 2017)

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: The independent variable (IV) is the variable that is manipulated or selected by the researcher to determine its effect on behavior. The dependent variable (DV) is the measured outcome that is expected to change as a function of the independent variable (Kerlinger & Lee, 2000)

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Extraneous variables are variables other than the IV that could potentially influence the DV. When an extraneous variable systematically varies with the IV, it becomes a confounding variable , making it impossible to determine whether the IV or the confound caused changes in the DV

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: A mediating variable explains the mechanism through which an IV affects a DV. It represents the pathway or process by which the effect occurs. A moderating variable affects the strength or direction of the relationship between an IV and DV—it identifies when or for whom an effect occurs (Baron & Kenny, 1986)

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Stevens (1946) identified four scales of measurement, often remembered by the mnemonic NOIR : Nominal, Ordinal, Interval, and Ratio. The scale of measurement determines which mathematical operations and statistical procedures are appropriate for the data

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: The nominal scale uses numbers only as labels or names for categories. Numbers cannot be meaningfully added, subtracted, or compared in terms of magnitude. Examples include gender (1 = male, 2 = female), diagnostic categories, or political party affiliation

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: The ordinal scale ranks observations from lowest to highest but does not specify the distance between ranks. The difference between ranks 1 and 2 may not equal the difference between ranks 2 and 3. Examples include class rank, Likert-type scales, and socioeconomic status categories

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: The interval scale has equal intervals between values but no true zero point. The zero is arbitrary, and ratios are not meaningful. The classic example is temperature in Fahrenheit or Celsius—the difference between 20° and 30° equals the difference between 70° and 80°, but 40° is not "twice as hot" as 20°

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Most psychological tests are treated as interval scales. Appropriate statistics include mean, standard deviation, Pearson correlation, t-tests, and ANOVA

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: The ratio scale has all the properties of the interval scale plus a true zero point representing the absence of the measured attribute. Ratios are meaningful—10 seconds is twice as long as 5 seconds. Examples include reaction time, number of errors, height, and weight

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Descriptive statistics summarize and organize data to make patterns more interpretable. They fall into three main categories: measures of central tendency, measures of variability, and measures of relative position

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: The mean (M or X̄) is the arithmetic average, calculated by summing all scores and dividing by the number of scores. It uses information from every score but is sensitive to extreme values (outliers). The mean is appropriate for interval and ratio data

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: The median (Mdn) is the middle score when data are arranged in order. It is less affected by outliers than the mean and is appropriate for ordinal, interval, and ratio data. In a skewed distribution, the median better represents the typical score

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: The mode is the most frequently occurring score. It is the only measure of central tendency appropriate for nominal data. A distribution can be bimodal (two modes) or multimodal (multiple modes)

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: The range is the difference between the highest and lowest scores. It is simple but unstable because it is based on only two scores and is highly sensitive to outliers

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: The variance (s² or σ²) is the average of the squared deviations from the mean. Squaring the deviations ensures that positive and negative deviations do not cancel out. Sample variance uses n-1 in the denominator to provide an unbiased estimate of population variance

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: The standard deviation (SD or s) is the square root of the variance, returning the measure to the original unit of measurement. It represents the average distance of scores from the mean and is the most commonly used measure of variability

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: The normal distribution (also called the Gaussian distribution or bell curve) is a theoretical probability distribution that is symmetric, unimodal, and asymptotic. Many psychological variables approximate normal distributions in large samples, and the normal distribution underlies many statistical procedures

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: A z-score (standard score) expresses a raw score in terms of how many standard deviations it falls above or below the mean. Z-scores allow comparison of scores from different distributions by converting them to a common scale

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Real data often deviate from the normal distribution. Two important characteristics describe the shape of distributions: skewness and kurtosis

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Skewness refers to the asymmetry of a distribution. In a positively skewed distribution, the tail extends toward higher values (right), and the mean is greater than the median. In a negatively skewed distribution, the tail extends toward lower values (left), and the mean is less than the median

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: Kurtosis describes the "peakedness" of a distribution and the heaviness of its tails. Leptokurtic distributions are more peaked with heavier tails than normal (positive kurtosis). Platykurtic distributions are flatter with lighter tails (negative kurtosis). Mesokurtic distributions have the same kurtosis as the normal distribution

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: A percentile rank indicates the percentage of scores in a distribution that fall at or below a given score. A score at the 75th percentile (P75) exceeds 75% of scores in the distribution

passages.chapter_title: Variables, Scales & the Language of Data
passages.passage: A percentile point (or percentile) is the score at or below which a specified percentage of scores falls. The 75th percentile point is the score that 75% of examinees scored at or below
